awd_titl_txt: Engineering the Metal Sulfide Interface in All Solid State Batteries through Operando Study
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a critical need for improved energy storage technologies for electric vehicles and large-scale integration of renewable electricity grid storage to improve domestic energy security. Currently, state-of-the-art energy storage technologies such as lithium ion batteries are insufficient in providing the performance requirements needed such as cost and energy density to enable broad use. Battery chemistries using high energy density electrodes and solid-state electrolytes could provide an avenue towards gains in energy density and durability for these applications. This project is a fundamental research study of solid-state electrolytes, a key component that enables these high energy density battery chemistries along with safety and durability benefits. Sulfide composites are promising as solid electrolytes in all solid-state batteries due to their high ionic conductivity and favorable mechanical strength features. However, sulfide solid electrolytes still face challenges that limit their use. This project will result in fundamental understanding of the mechanisms and material interactions of metal sulfides in all solid-state batteries. The research will guide improvements to material design, improved electrolytes and electrodes, and eventually lead to improved designs for high energy, solid-state batteries. Society will also benefit from the training of highly qualified researchers who will be able to continue technology improvements in creating large-scale energy solutions from science, technology, engineering, and math disciplines.

The specific objective of this research is to improve metal sulfide stability in solid-state electrolytes for the application of all solid-state lithium batteries. In pursuit of this objective, the fundamental mechanisms of metal sulfide ion conduction and interface reactivity will be interrogated by operando characterization carried out on realistic, fully operational battery cells. This will reveal the critical materials evolution processes occurring at buried interfaces within sealed devices during cycling. The findings will be used to modify the metal sulfide chemistry through elementary doping and to stabilize the interface through interface engineering. This will be accomplished by the convergent effort of two research groups, one with expertise in synthesis and materials engineering, interface stabilization, and cell modification, and one skilled in operando characterization and modeling of batteries. The methodology in this work ? combining materials synthesis and evaluation, operando device characterization, and computation ? will lead to an in-depth understanding of the thermodynamic, kinetic, electrochemical, chemomechanical, and structural stability of metal sulfide all solid-state batteries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Rising global energy needs demand next-generation batteries with higher energy density, power, and safety. Metal sulfide solid electrolytes have shown potential to meet these needs but face fundamental stability issues regarding voltage, electrode compatibility, and air stability that have hindered practical applications. This project aimed to address these challenges and advance metal sulfide electrolytes through an integrated approach combining materials synthesis, operando characterization, and modeling.

The project team implemented a five-pronged approach:

  1. Operando energy dispersive X-ray diffraction (EDXRD) interrogation of buried interfaces during battery cycling revealed evolution of interfacial species.
  2. Conduction mechanisms and interfacial reaction pathways were elucidated through coordinated electrochemical testing and structural characterization.
  3. Electrolyte modifications including doping were conducted and iteratively evaluated.
  4. Interfacial stability was targeted through nanoengineering approaches based on insights into degradation.
  5. Performance enhancements were systematically assessed to provide feedback for additional optimization.

Through these efforts, this project delivered comprehensive in-depth understanding of the multifaceted stability issues plaguing sulfide electrolytes across kinetic, electrochemical, mechanical, and structural domains. The operando focus on realistic battery cycling provided unprecedented insights into internal material and morphology changes during function, enabling targeted strategies to overcome limitations.

Modified electrolytes and optimized interfaces are critical steps toward enabling commercially viable sulfide-based solid-state batteries. The operando EDXRD experiments ensure data reflects actual electrochemical cycling effects within sealed cells. These fundamental advances elucidate design principles to transform sulfide electrolyte performance and stability. Key outcomes include electrode coatings that improve interfacial compatibility and new doping approaches that expand stability windows.

The project outcomes significantly advance all-solid-state battery technology and benefit society through enabling transformative high energy density batteries. The enhanced safety of sulfide solid electrolytes could accelerate electric vehicle adoption and sustainability. Lighter, smaller batteries could also revolutionize portable electronics. Student researchers involved gained valuable skills and mindsets to drive future energy solutions. By emphasizing elucidation of fundamental science underlying technological leaps, this project sets the stage for widespread sulfide electrolyte integration.

In summary, this project established a framework to overcome the core stability roadblocks hindering metal sulfide solid electrolyte batteries through comprehensive understanding of failure mechanisms, interface engineering and ceramic solid electrolyte doping. The discoveries provide a launching point for additional research to further progress toward enabling high-performance, versatile sulfide based all solid state batteries and catalyzing their widespread integration across applications. Continued development building on these operando insights will be key to unlocking the full potential of sulfide electrolytes. More detailed publication can be found in the group webpage: https://coe.northeastern.edu/research/hongli_group/publication.html

 


Last Modified: 10/20/2023
Modified by: Hongli Zhu
